thread.title: Subiaco Oval no enemy territory as West Coast fans welcome their Adelaide counterparts |
thread.title_full: Subiaco Oval no enemy territory as West Coast fans welcome their Adelaide counterparts | The Advertiser

author: Michelangelo Rucci
title: Subiaco Oval no enemy territory as West Coast fans welcome their Adelaide counterparts |
text:
GLENGOWRIE couple Bill and Sue Jesser were the first Crows fans to enter Subiaco Oval this afternoon for the Phil Walsh tribute match, gaining a hug, kiss and the best wishes from West Coast members.
“One of their fans just hugged me, kissed me ... and said this is one time we can wish you luck,” Sue Jesser said as she took her seat just to the right of the Adelaide coach’s box.
On their first trip to Perth, the devoted Crows fans paid $110 each for tickets sent back by West Coast members unable to attend tonight’s AFL game.
“Even if it was $200, we still would have come,” said Mr Jesser, who took time from managing a security company to be at the Crows’ first game since the death of senior coach Walsh at his Somerton Park home last week.
“We’re still in shock, but we had to be here to show our bit of support for the boys.”
The Jessers are among 600 Crows fans based around Australia who have bought tickets through the West Coast exchange program or from the WA Crows Supporter Group.
Former Adelaide resident Steve Young, the leader of the WA Crows Supporter Group, said tickets to West Coast games were “usually impossible to get”.
“But with the help of the Crows staff back in Adelaide and with some West Coast members saying they can’t come to a game that is so emotionally charged, we have been able to get everyone in,” Mr Young said.
